page.title: 13 Changing times
page.content: We interviewed a lady who has lived in Whitstable for about 60 years. This is what she said,"Children were at school until the age 14,classes were larger and the work less varied and there was less choice of schools.During the war men were in the services so women had to do the mens work.Many people were involved in the fishing industry, especially in shellfish.Whitstable used to be a small town, not many people had cars but now most people drive to work and many families have two cars.Trains ran more frequently and there was a train service between Whitstable and Canterbury.The shops were small and more varied, there were no supermarkets and the only takeaway food shop was fish and chips.Food was rationed but people ate a healthier diet.The town has grown in size but has still retained its character."
